# Ovarian cyst

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Ovarian cyst  
---  
[![Benign Ovarian
Cyst.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Benign_Ovarian_Cyst.jpg/300px-
Benign_Ovarian_Cyst.jpg)](/wiki/File:Benign_Ovarian_Cyst.jpg)  
A simple ovarian cyst of most likely follicular origin  
[Specialty](/wiki/Specialty_\(medicine\) "Specialty \(medicine\)") | [Gynecology](/wiki/Gynecology "Gynecology")  
Symptoms | None, bloating, lower abdominal pain, lower back pain[1]  
[Complications](/wiki/Complication_\(medicine\) "Complication \(medicine\)") | [Rupture](/wiki/Ruptured_ovarian_cyst "Ruptured ovarian cyst"), [twisting of the ovary](/wiki/Ovarian_torsion "Ovarian torsion")[1]  
Types | [Follicular cyst](/wiki/Follicular_cyst_of_ovary "Follicular cyst of ovary"), [corpus luteum cyst](/wiki/Corpus_luteum_cyst "Corpus luteum cyst"), [cysts due to endometriosis](/wiki/Endometrioma "Endometrioma"), [dermoid cyst](/wiki/Dermoid_cyst "Dermoid cyst"), [cystadenoma](/wiki/Cystadenoma "Cystadenoma"), [ovarian cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian cancer")[1]  
[Diagnostic method](/wiki/Diagnostic_method "Diagnostic method") | [Ultrasound](/wiki/Ultrasound "Ultrasound")[1]  
Prevention | [Hormonal birth control](/wiki/Hormonal_birth_control "Hormonal birth control")[1]  
Treatment | [Conservative management](/wiki/Conservative_management "Conservative management"), pain medication, surgery[1]  
Prognosis | Usually good[1]  
Frequency | 8% symptomatic before [menopause](/wiki/Menopause "Menopause")[1]  
[[edit on Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q147362 "d:Q147362")]  
  
An **ovarian cyst** is a fluid-filled sac within the [ovary](/wiki/Ovary
"Ovary").[1] Often they cause no symptoms.[1] Occasionally they may produce
bloating, lower abdominal pain, or lower back pain.[1] The majority of cysts
are harmless.[1] If the cyst either [breaks open](/wiki/Ruptured_ovarian_cyst
"Ruptured ovarian cyst") or causes [twisting of the
ovary](/wiki/Ovarian_torsion "Ovarian torsion"), it may cause severe pain.[1]
This may result in vomiting or [feeling faint](/wiki/Lightheadedness
"Lightheadedness").[1]

Most ovarian cysts are related to [ovulation](/wiki/Ovulation "Ovulation"),
being either [follicular cysts](/wiki/Follicular_cyst_of_ovary "Follicular
cyst of ovary") or [corpus luteum cysts](/wiki/Corpus_luteum_cyst "Corpus
luteum cyst").[1] Other types include [cysts due to
endometriosis](/wiki/Endometrioma "Endometrioma"), [dermoid
cysts](/wiki/Dermoid_cyst "Dermoid cyst"), and
[cystadenomas](/wiki/Cystadenoma "Cystadenoma").[1] Many small cysts occur in
both ovaries in [polycystic ovarian
syndrome](/wiki/Polycystic_ovarian_syndrome "Polycystic ovarian syndrome").[1]
[Pelvic inflammatory disease](/wiki/Pelvic_inflammatory_disease "Pelvic
inflammatory disease") may also result in cysts.[1] Rarely, cysts may be a
form of [ovarian cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian cancer").[1] Diagnosis
is undertaken by [pelvic examination](/wiki/Pelvic_examination "Pelvic
examination") with an [ultrasound](/wiki/Ultrasound "Ultrasound") or other
testing used to gather further details.[1]

Often, cysts are simply observed over time.[1] If they cause pain, medications
such as [paracetamol](/wiki/Paracetamol "Paracetamol") (acetaminophen) or
[ibuprofen](/wiki/Ibuprofen "Ibuprofen") may be used.[1] [Hormonal birth
control](/wiki/Hormonal_birth_control "Hormonal birth control") may be used to
prevent further cysts in those who are frequently affected.[1] However,
evidence does not support birth control as a treatment of current cysts.[2] If
they do not go away after several months, get larger, look unusual, or cause
pain, they may be removed by surgery.[1]

Most women of reproductive age develop small cysts each month.[1] Large cysts
that cause problems occur in about 8% of women before
[menopause](/wiki/Menopause "Menopause").[1] Ovarian cysts are present in
about 16% of women after menopause and if present are more likely to be
cancer.[1][3]

## Signs and
symptoms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Signs and symptoms")]

Some or all of the following symptoms may be present, though it is possible
not to experience any symptoms:[4]

  * [Abdominal](/wiki/Abdomen "Abdomen") pain. Dull aching pain within the abdomen or pelvis, especially during intercourse.
  * [Uterine](/wiki/Uterus "Uterus") bleeding. Pain during or shortly after beginning or end of menstrual period; irregular periods, or abnormal uterine bleeding or spotting.
  * Fullness, heaviness, pressure, swelling, or [bloating](/wiki/Bloating "Bloating") in the abdomen.
  * When a cyst ruptures from the [ovary](/wiki/Ovary "Ovary"), there may be sudden and sharp pain in the lower abdomen on one side.
  * Change in frequency or ease of [urination](/wiki/Urination "Urination") (such as inability to fully empty the [bladder](/wiki/Urinary_bladder "Urinary bladder")), or difficulty with [bowel movements](/wiki/Bowel_movement "Bowel movement") due to pressure on adjacent [pelvic](/wiki/Pelvic "Pelvic") anatomy.
  * [Constitutional symptoms](/wiki/Constitutional_symptom "Constitutional symptom") such as [fatigue](/wiki/Fatigue_\(physical\) "Fatigue \(physical\)"), [headaches](/wiki/Headache "Headache")
  * Nausea or vomiting
  * Weight gain

Other symptoms may depend on the cause of the cysts:[4]

  * Symptoms that may occur if the cause of the cysts is [polycystic ovarian syndrome](/wiki/Polycystic_ovarian_syndrome "Polycystic ovarian syndrome") (PCOS) may include increased [facial hair](/wiki/Facial_hair "Facial hair") or [body hair](/wiki/Body_hair "Body hair"), [acne](/wiki/Acne "Acne"), obesity and [infertility](/wiki/Infertility "Infertility").
  * If the cause is [endometriosis](/wiki/Endometriosis "Endometriosis"), then periods may be heavy, and intercourse painful.

The effect of cysts not related to PCOS on fertility is unclear.[5]

### Cyst rupture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cyst rupture")]

A [ruptured ovarian cyst](/wiki/Ruptured_ovarian_cyst "Ruptured ovarian cyst")
is usually self-limiting, and only requires keeping an eye on the situation
and [pain medications](/wiki/Analgesic "Analgesic"). The main symptom is
abdominal pain, which may last a few days to a several weeks, but they can
also be asymptomatic.[6] Rupture of large ovarian cysts can cause [bleeding
inside the abdominal cavity](/wiki/Hemoperitoneum "Hemoperitoneum") and in
some cases shock.

### Ovarian
torsion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Ovarian torsion")]

Ovarian cysts increase the risk for [ovarian torsion](/wiki/Ovarian_torsion
"Ovarian torsion"); cysts larger than 4 cm are associated with approximately
17% risk. The torsion can cause obstruction of blood flow and lead to
[infarction](/wiki/Infarction "Infarction").[7]

## Diagnosis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Diagnosis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/2cmleftovariancyst.png/220px-2cmleftovariancyst.png)](/wiki/File:2cmleftovariancyst.png)

[](/wiki/File:2cmleftovariancyst.png "Enlarge")

A 2 cm left ovarian cyst as seen on ultrasound

Ovarian cysts are usually diagnosed by [ultrasound](/wiki/Ultrasound
"Ultrasound"), [CT scan](/wiki/CT_scan "CT scan"), or
[MRI](/wiki/Magnetic_resonance_imaging "Magnetic resonance imaging"), and
correlated with clinical presentation and endocrinologic tests as appropriate.

### Ultrasound[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Ultrasound")]

Follow-up imaging in women of reproductive age for incidentally discovered
simple cysts on ultrasound is not needed until 5 cm, as these are usually
normal ovarian follicles. Simple cysts 5 to 7 cm in
[premenopausal](/wiki/Menopause#Diagnosis "Menopause") females should be
followed yearly. Simple cysts larger than 7 cm require further imaging with
[MRI](/wiki/Magnetic_resonance_imaging "Magnetic resonance imaging") or
surgical assessment. Because they are large, they cannot be reliably assessed
by ultrasound alone because it may be difficult to see the soft tissue
nodularity or thickened septation at their posterior wall due to limited
penetrance of the ultrasound beam. For the [corpus luteum](/wiki/Corpus_luteum
"Corpus luteum"), a dominant ovulating follicle that typically appears as a
cyst with circumferentially thickened walls and [crenulated](/wiki/Crenulation
"Crenulation") inner margins, follow up is not needed if the cyst is less than
3 cm in diameter. In [postmenopausal](/wiki/Menopause#Diagnosis "Menopause")
patients, any simple cyst greater than 1 cm but less than 7 cm needs yearly
follow-up, while those greater than 7 cm need MRI or surgical evaluation,
similar to reproductive age females.[8]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Ovarian_Cyst.JPG/220px-
Ovarian_Cyst.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ovarian_Cyst.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ovarian_Cyst.JPG "Enlarge")

An Axial CT demonstrating a large hemorrhagic ovarian cyst. The cyst is
delineated by the yellow bars with blood seen anteriorly.

For incidentally discovered [dermoids](/wiki/Dermoid_cyst "Dermoid cyst"),
diagnosed on ultrasound by their [pathognomonic](/wiki/Pathognomonic
"Pathognomonic") [echogenic](/wiki/Echogenicity "Echogenicity") fat, either
surgical removal or yearly follow up is indicated, regardless of patient age.
For [peritoneal inclusion cysts](/wiki/Peritoneal_inclusion_cysts "Peritoneal
inclusion cysts"), which have a crumpled tissue-paper appearance and tend to
follow the contour of adjacent organs, follow up is based on clinical history.
[Hydrosalpinx](/wiki/Hydrosalpinx "Hydrosalpinx"), or [fallopian
tube](/wiki/Fallopian_tube "Fallopian tube") dilation, can be mistaken for an
ovarian cyst due to its anechoic appearance. Follow-up for this is also based
on clinical presentation.[8]

For multiloculate cysts with thin septation less than 3 mm, surgical
evaluation is recommended. The presence of multiloculation suggests a
[neoplasm](/wiki/Neoplasm "Neoplasm"), although the thin septation implies
that the neoplasm is benign. For any thickened septation, nodularity, or
vascular flow on [color doppler](/wiki/Color_doppler "Color doppler")
assessment, surgical removal should be considered due to concern for
malignancy.[8]

### Scoring
systems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Scoring systems")]

There are several systems to assess risk of an ovarian cyst of being an
[ovarian cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian cancer"), including the RMI
(risk of malignancy index), LR2 and SR (simple rules). [Sensitivities and
specificities](/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity "Sensitivity and
specificity") of these systems are given in tables below:[9]

Scoring systems | Premenopausal | Postmenopausal  
---|---|---  
Sensitivity | Specificity | Sensitivity | Specificity  
RMI I | 44% | 95% | 79% | 90%  
LR2 | 85% | 91% | 94% | 70%  
SR | 93% | 83% | 93% | 76%  
  
Ovarian cysts may be classified according to whether they are a variant of the
normal [menstrual cycle](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle "Menstrual cycle"), referred to
as a functional or follicular cyst.[4]

Ovarian cysts are considered large when they are over 5 cm and giant when they
are over 15 cm. In children, ovarian cysts reaching above the level of the
umbilicus are considered giant.

### Functional[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Functional")]

Functional cysts form as a normal part of the menstrual cycle. There are
several types of cysts:

  * [Follicular cyst](/wiki/Follicular_cyst_of_ovary "Follicular cyst of ovary"), the most common type of ovarian cyst. In menstruating women, a follicle containing the [ovum](/wiki/Ovum "Ovum"), an unfertilized egg, will rupture during ovulation. If this does not occur, a follicular cyst of more than 2.5 cm diameter may result.[4]
  * [Corpus luteum cysts](/wiki/Corpus_luteum_cyst "Corpus luteum cyst") appear after ovulation. The [corpus luteum](/wiki/Corpus_luteum "Corpus luteum") is the remnant of the follicle after the ovum has moved to the [fallopian tubes](/wiki/Fallopian_tube "Fallopian tube"). This normally degrades within 5 to 9 days. A corpus luteum that is more than 3 cm is defined as cystic.[4]
  * [Theca lutein cysts](/wiki/Theca_lutein_cyst "Theca lutein cyst") occur within the [thecal layer](/wiki/Ovarian_follicle#Thecal "Ovarian follicle") of cells surrounding developing oocytes. Under the influence of excessive [hCG](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin "Human chorionic gonadotropin"), thecal cells may proliferate and become cystic. This is usually on both ovaries.[4]

### Non-
functional[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Non-functional")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Hemorrhagic_ovarian_cyst.jpg/220px-
Hemorrhagic_ovarian_cyst.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hemorrhagic_ovarian_cyst.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hemorrhagic_ovarian_cyst.jpg "Enlarge")

[Transvaginal ultrasonography](/wiki/Transvaginal_ultrasonography
"Transvaginal ultrasonography") of a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst, probably
originating from a [corpus luteum cyst](/wiki/Corpus_luteum_cyst "Corpus
luteum cyst"). The coagulating blood gives the content a cobweb-like
appearance.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Endometrioma.jpg/220px-
Endometrioma.jpg)](/wiki/File:Endometrioma.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Endometrioma.jpg "Enlarge")

[Transvaginal ultrasonography](/wiki/Transvaginal_ultrasonography
"Transvaginal ultrasonography") showing a 67 x 40 mm
[endometrioma](/wiki/Endometrioma "Endometrioma"), with a somewhat grainy
content.

Non-functional cysts may include the following:

  * An ovary with many cysts, which may be found in normal women, or within the setting of [polycystic ovary syndrome](/wiki/Polycystic_ovary_syndrome "Polycystic ovary syndrome")
  * Cysts caused by [endometriosis](/wiki/Endometriosis "Endometriosis"), known as [chocolate cysts](/wiki/Chocolate_cyst_of_ovary "Chocolate cyst of ovary")
  * Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst
  * [Dermoid cyst](/wiki/Dermoid_cyst "Dermoid cyst")
  * [Ovarian serous cystadenoma](/wiki/Ovarian_serous_cystadenoma "Ovarian serous cystadenoma")
  * Ovarian [mucinous cystadenoma](/wiki/Mucinous_cystadenoma "Mucinous cystadenoma")
  * [Paraovarian cyst](/wiki/Paraovarian_cyst "Paraovarian cyst")
  * Cystic adenofibroma
  * Borderline tumoral cysts

### Associated medical
conditions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Associated medical conditions")]

In juvenile [hypothyroidism](/wiki/Hypothyroidism "Hypothyroidism")
multicystic ovaries are present in about 75% of cases, while large ovarian
cysts and elevated ovarian tumor marks are one of the symptoms of the [Van Wyk
and Grumbach syndrome](/wiki/Van_Wyk_and_Grumbach_syndrome "Van Wyk and
Grumbach syndrome").[10]

The CA-125 marker in children and adolescents can be frequently elevated even
in absence of malignancy and conservative management should be considered.

[Polycystic ovarian syndrome](/wiki/Polycystic_ovarian_syndrome "Polycystic
ovarian syndrome") involves the development of multiple small cysts in both
ovaries due to an elevated ratio of [leutenizing
hormone](/wiki/Leutenizing_hormone "Leutenizing hormone") to [follicle
stimulating hormone](/wiki/Follicle_stimulating_hormone "Follicle stimulating
hormone"), typically more than 25 cysts in each ovary, or an ovarian volume of
greater than 10 mL.[11]

Larger bilateral cysts can develop as a result of [fertility
treatment](/wiki/Assisted_reproductive_technology "Assisted reproductive
technology") due to elevated levels of
[HCG](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin "Human chorionic gonadotropin"), as
can be seen with the use of [clomifene](/wiki/Clomifene "Clomifene") for
follicular induction, in extreme cases resulting in a condition known as
[ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome](/wiki/Ovarian_hyperstimulation_syndrome
"Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome").[12] Certain malignancies can mimic the
effects of clomifene on the ovaries, also due to [increased
HCG](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin#Uses "Human chorionic gonadotropin"),
in particular [gestational trophoblastic
disease](/wiki/Gestational_trophoblastic_disease "Gestational trophoblastic
disease"). Ovarian hyperstimulation occurs more often with invasive moles and
choriocarcinoma than complete molar pregnancies.[13]

### Risk of
cancer[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Risk of cancer")]

A widely recognised method of estimating the risk of malignant ovarian cancer
based on initial workup is the _risk of malignancy index_ (RMI).[14] It is
recommended that women with an RMI score over 200 should be referred to a
centre with experience in ovarian cancer surgery.[15]

The RMI is calculated as follows:[15]

    RMI = ultrasound score x menopausal score x CA-125 level in U/ml.

There are two methods to determine the ultrasound score and menopausal score,
with the resultant RMI being called RMI 1 and RMI 2, respectively, depending
on what method is used:[15]

Feature | RMI 1 | RMI 2  
---|---|---  
Ultrasound abnormalities:

  * Multilocular cyst
  * Solid areas
  * Bilateral lesions
  * [Ascites](/wiki/Ascites "Ascites")
  * Intra-abdominal metastases

|

  * 0 = no abnormality
  * 1 = one abnormality
  * 3 = two or more abnormalities

|

  * 0 = none
  * 1 = one abnormality
  * 4 = two or more abnormalities

  
Menopausal score | 

  * 1 = premenopausal
  * 3 = postmenopausal

|

  * 1 = premenopausal
  * 4 = postmenopausal

  
CA-125 | Quantity in U/ml | Quantity in U/ml  
  
An RMI 2 of over 200 has been estimated to have a
[sensitivity](/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity "Sensitivity and specificity")
of 74 to 80%, a [specificity](/wiki/Sensitivity_and_specificity "Sensitivity
and specificity") of 89 to 92% and a [positive predictive
value](/wiki/Positive_predictive_value "Positive predictive value") of around
80% of ovarian cancer.[15] RMI 2 is regarded as more sensitive than RMI 1.[15]

## Treatment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Treatment")]

Cysts associated with [hypothyroidism](/wiki/Hypothyroidism "Hypothyroidism")
or other [endocrine](/wiki/Endocrine_system "Endocrine system") problems are
managed by treating the underlying condition.

About 95% of ovarian cysts are [benign](/wiki/Benign "Benign"), not
cancerous.[16]

Functional cysts and hemorrhagic ovarian cysts usually resolve
spontaneously.[17] However, the bigger an ovarian cyst is, the less likely it
is to disappear on its own.[18] Treatment may be required if cysts persist
over several months, grow, or cause increasing pain.[19]

Cysts that persist beyond two or three [menstrual
cycles](/wiki/Menstrual_cycle "Menstrual cycle"), or occur in
post-[menopausal](/wiki/Menopausal "Menopausal") women, may indicate more
serious disease and should be investigated through
[ultrasonography](/wiki/Ultrasonography "Ultrasonography") and
[laparoscopy](/wiki/Laparoscopy "Laparoscopy"), especially in cases where
family members have had [ovarian cancer](/wiki/Ovarian_cancer "Ovarian
cancer"). Such cysts may require surgical [biopsy](/wiki/Biopsy "Biopsy").
Additionally, a [blood test](/wiki/Blood_test "Blood test") may be taken
before surgery to check for elevated [CA-125](/wiki/CA-125 "CA-125"), a
[tumour marker](/wiki/Tumour_marker "Tumour marker"), which is often found in
increased levels in ovarian cancer, although it can also be elevated by other
conditions resulting in a large number of false positives.[20]

### Pain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Pain")]

Pain associated with ovarian cysts may be treated in several ways:

  * [Pain relievers](/wiki/Pain_reliever "Pain reliever") such as [acetaminophen](/wiki/Acetaminophen "Acetaminophen"), [nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs](/wiki/Nonsteroidal_anti-inflammatory_drugs "Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs"),[1] or [opioids](/wiki/Opioids "Opioids").
  * While [hormonal birth control](/wiki/Hormonal_birth_control "Hormonal birth control") prevents the development of new cysts in those who frequently get them,[1] it is not useful for the treatment of current cysts.[2]

### Surgery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Surgery")]

Although most cases of ovarian cysts involve monitoring, some cases require
surgery.[21] This may involve removing the cyst, or [one or both
ovaries](/wiki/Oopherectomy "Oopherectomy").[22] Technique is typically
[laparoscopic](/wiki/Laparoscopic "Laparoscopic"), unless the cyst is
particularly large, or if pre-operative imaging suggests malignancy or complex
anatomy.[23] In certain situations, the cyst is entirely
[removed](/wiki/Resection_\(surgery\) "Resection \(surgery\)"), while with
cysts with low recurrence risk, younger patients, or which are in anatomically
eloquent areas of the pelvis, they can be drained.[24][25] Features that may
indicate the need for surgery include:[26]

  * Persistent complex ovarian cysts
  * Persistent cysts that are causing symptoms
  * Complex ovarian cysts larger than 5 cm
  * Simple ovarian cysts larger 10 cm or larger than 5 cm in postmenopausal patients
  * Women who are menopausal or [perimenopausal](/wiki/Perimenopausal "Perimenopausal")

## Frequency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ovarian_cyst&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Frequency")]

Most women of reproductive age develop small cysts each month, and large cysts
that cause problems occur in about 8% of women before
[menopause](/wiki/Menopause "Menopause").[1] Ovarian cysts are present in
about 16% of women after menopause and if present are more likely to be
cancer.[1][3]

Benign ovarian cysts are common in asymptomatic premenarchal girls and found
in approximately 68% of ovaries of girls 2–12 years old and in 84% of ovaries
of girls 0–2 years old. Most of them are smaller than 9 mm while about 10-20%
are larger [macrocysts](/wiki/Macrocyst "Macrocyst"). While the smaller cysts
mostly disappear within 6 months the larger ones appear to be more
persistent.[27][28]
